↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Do you guys think twtxt/yarn should have 2 factor auth system? I know good passwords is enough but it would be more better if twtxt/yarn have 2FA/2 factor auth.

@akoizumi@kyoko.nerdpol.ovh That‚Äôs true but I have found libraries that can help us implement TOTP so it should be pretty easy to add support for üëå

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Do you guys think twtxt/yarn should have 2 factor auth system? I know good passwords is enough but it would be more better if twtxt/yarn have 2FA/2 factor auth.

@koelopog16@yn.vern.cc Yes I think Yarn.social pods running yarnd should have builtin support for TOTP / 2FA. Absolutely! If there isn‚Äôt already an existing Issue for this, please file one üôè My only requirement is that we built it in a way that is self-hosted and not reliant on any 3rd-party ‚Äúcloud‚Äù / ‚Äúsaas‚Äù service. It has to work on its own.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Do you think Yarn should have some sort of desktop app or mobile app for the platform?

@koelopog16@yn.vern.cc It in fact does have a Mobile App (code-named Goryon) over at https://git.mills.io/yarnsocial/app ‚Äì We haven‚Äôt yet published it, but it should be installable depending on what platform you‚Äôre on‚Ä¶

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª We've had about ~20 or so new folks join Yarn.social / Twtxt in over the past ~2 weeks or so ü•≥ Its not as many as Mastodon's ~70k new folks, but its still non-zero ü§£ Media

@koelopog16@yn.vern.cc Oh hey! üëã What‚Äôs even nicer is the fact I easily discovered you through the ‚ÄúDiscover‚Äù view üòÖ And yeah it is nice to see out little niche ‚Äúsocial‚Äù thingy (some have called it the non-social social media ü§£) grow over time ü•≥

Current Feature Flags - yarn - Mills ‚Äì Write up a quick Wiki page describing the current set of features that can be enabled on Yarn.social pods by operators (running yarnd) that are currently in flight üëå

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Thinking about reviving (#xi7nivq) - the idea of managing bashblog comments with twtxt instead of leading people to Twitter.

@marado This approach is fine, as long as you‚Äôre aware that there is no way to actually attribute the authorship of the line in the feed that is essentially being used to let (potentially) anonymous visitors to your site/blog add comments.

I‚Äôve given this a lot of thought over the months and I think the best way to solve for this in general over time is to a) Build support for micro.Pub into yarnd b) Add support for IndieAuth (as a consumer) and then build out an ecosystem of Javascript and whatever libraries and tools to support this use-case.

This way when someone makes a comment on a blog post or website, they are in fact logging into their feed on some pod (that you choose to use) and they are able to take that with them, or continue using it, etc.

Just my $0.20 worth üòÖ

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª "the cloud is just someone else's computer" is incorrect. the cloud is someone else's oncall rotation.

@maya@maya.land ‚ÄúThe Cloud‚Äù is still someone else‚Äôs computer or bunch of computers. The important point here is data locality, data security and authenticity.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Thinking about reviving (#xi7nivq) - the idea of managing bashblog comments with twtxt instead of leading people to Twitter.

@marado So I did üòÖ So the simplest way to do this is to just either use yarnc post or the API or even just write a line to your feed that announces your blog post. Use that as the Yarn/thread to place comments again üòÖ

The ‚Äúscope‚Äù will blow out when you want to do things like:

  • Allow arbitrary internet users to comment, so you‚Äôd have to do something around identity and maybe creating ephemeral feds for them.
  • Searching for previous comments and displaying them.

Although the 2nd point is probably not so bad, just have to get integrated search into pods now that search.twtxt.net is mostly done üëå (still needs an API I reckon? ü§î)

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Hello there fellow humans.

@montsamu@twtxt.net Hello! üëã Welcome to Yarn.social ü§ó

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @marado I'm serving my twtxt in Spanish on Gemini as well, and perhaps we could serve Yarn/twtxt.net on a proxy.

Yarn/Twtxt is in fact fully decentralized üòÜ

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª One of the things that attracts me about the "twtxt social network" is how radically decentralized it is. Not only each user is its own node (maintaining its own text file feed), there's no limits to the protocols used to access each feed. Sure, most of the feeds are probably being served over http or https, but there are feeds being served over gopher, and I bet some of them over ftp/ftps. But it doesn't have to be that way - feeds can be distributed in any modern equivalent to the sneakernet, you can save yours in a usb stick or a floppy disk, hand it over by hand or send it via postal mail; you can distributed them on a mailing list, on the usernet... The limit is your imagination. This reflection made me realize that there's no reason to wait for secushare, twtxt feeds can already be used, shared, maintained and spread on GNUnet, taking this social media platform to the GNU Internet.

@mckinley@twtxt.net Also well said üëå

Otherwise I have to create multiple ones, just wild animals, just sunsets/-rises, just other skies, just landscapes, just macros etc. Also, any good software that helps with selecting the best takes?
